heading: Planning
content: The group met and collectively took decisions about different things. Different team members were given different duties to read the documentation/datasheets of the various components to be used. They were also told learning which topics would help them to contribute to this project.

heading: Buying things
content: We went to Jatni to buy Aluminium box pipes (Rs450/10ft) for the arms of the drone. We used switchboard plates (Sunmica) (Rs 120) for the upper and lower plates which will hold the metal arms in place. We also had to buy screws, nuts and bolts of different sizes. We also went to Bhubaneshwar once (later) to buy small screws and special rubber spacers for soft-mounting the flight controller.

heading: Basic Structure Built
content: Four equal-sized (~24cm) pieces were cut off from the long aluminium pipe for the arms. Holes were drilled into measured places of appropriate diameter. We took the help of the Central Workshop for drilling holes due to the unavailability of those appropriately sized drill bits in RTC. Later we bought those drill bits ourselves. We also cut 2 pieces of Sunmica, each of dimension 13*13cm. We drilled holes into it in appropriate positions. Then we attached the metal arms to the plates. We used two 1.5inch long M6 bolts for each arm (which makes up 8 nuts &bolts).

heading: Motors Attached
content: Four EMAX MT2213 920 kVA brushless motor were mounted on the mounting points of the drone arm. The mounting was done on additionally 3D printed spacers to accomodate the back opening of the motor shaft. The screws were fixed using four screew holes made in the lower part of the arm in order to complete fixing using Allen keys.

heading: Electronic components prepared for assembly
content: Each of the connections for motors, electronic speed controllers and power units were soldered accordingly using 20 gauge connecting wires, rated for carrying high current upto 25-30 A. The connections to the motor were made using plug socket attachment with the electronic speed controllers, insulated using heat shrinked rubber coverings so that they can be disconnected easily in case of removal due to damage.

heading: Assembly of the principal components of drone
content: The assembly was initiated by fixing the power module on the central base of the drone, and using additional 3D printed Hexagonal spacers, the soft mounting base was fixed above it. The electronic speed controllers were fixed to the arms of the drone using plastic strip cable zip ties, along with all the connecting wires to the motor, radio receiver antennas and the power module. The receiver module was placed in the central section of the drone base, along with a telemetry module. The PixHawk flight controller was soft mounted on the carbon fibre base using rubber spacers. Additional holes were made for fixing stand on which, the GPS module was fixed. All required connections were made to the power, receiver, telemetry and GPS module to the flight controller and the functioning of the components were tested using associated PixHawk software
